pros: Leadership doesn't micromanage the programs.
cons: Instructor requirements do not match the pay. This makes it hard to find a qualified applicant for open positions.

pros: The hours were great because it is almost totally a daytime college with weekends off, state holidays, federal holidays and a very generous Christmas holiday that enables you to have a vacation or relaxing family time without using your earned leave that you want to use at other times during the year.
cons: The pay is so low in most positions on campus. The instructors are paid far below their counterparts in the field. They come to TSTC for the slower pace and time off listed in my pros section but the lack of pay eventually forces most of the instructors to return to the field.

pros: Good people to work with.
cons: They like to pile the work on and toxic at times.

review_title: Easy enough work to do, not the easiest environment to work in.

pros: Tasks are auto-generated using CRM platform software, makes keeping track of to-dos really easy.
cons: The communication culture of the company is really unhealthy, super gossipy and very shallow, petty, and lacks the framework & practices to navigate conflict b/w coworkers in a healthy, relationship-building & repairing way.

pros: Friendly coworkers, very good immediate supervisor
cons: Very poor upper management who doesn’t support their educators.

pros: Benefits vacation time and sick pay

pros: Students are great. It is very rewarding teaching them for careers.

review_title: Good teammates, good leadership, low pay

cons: Low pay is a well known issue irrespective of department. Raises didn't keep up with inflation prior to the pandemic. The situation is worse now.

pros: Great place to work at if you are surrounded with the right people.
cons: Leadership unfairness, they preferred micromanaging leaders.

pros: Great Benefits good family environment

job_title: Executive Director of IT and Compliance in Waco, TX

pros: The job is simple, everyone is easygoing and as long as you do your work you won't have any issues.
cons: The pay is not great. Few opportunities for promotions.

pros: Literally some of the nicest people I've ever worked with. Family-friendly, and very flexible. Lots of creative problem solving.
cons: Problems are often created by a lack of planning and foresight. Is a Hispanic-Serving Institution where most of the professors and almost all the regional leadership is white.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Coach in Harlingen, TX
pros: Great supportive team and supervisors are great with work life balance
cons: No structure for majority of events/ changes. A lot of work since it is a one stop shop.

pros: Working here is generally great
cons: Some positions need to be paid better

review_title: Not so nice to employees anymore
job_title: Program Maintenance Specialist in Waco, TX
pros: Lots of days off for holidays/thanksgiving/christmas/new years.
cons: Constantly changing policies/procedures, very little consistency or loyalty to employees.

job_title: Assistant Director of Enrollment in Waco, TX
pros: The people here treat you like a family that cares! The chancellor and leadership make good choices and they care about the students most of all.
cons: State pay is what it is.

pros: Flexible with work study and okay pay
cons: Not much room for growth

review_title: No plans to ever leave TSTC
job_title: Dual Enrollment Recruitment Representative in Sweetwater, TX
pros: Supportive work environment in certain departments. I have worked in multiple departments and I have always experienced if you are a hard worker and always have your job done when times come up that require you to need flexibility TSTC and the supervisors are more than happy to assist however they can.
cons: Since it is a statewide company with multiple campuses sometimes communication about changes can get confusing.

review_title: It is what you get from a state institution.
pros: Depending on the direct supervisor, there is lots of free time and flexibility at the job. The benefits package is good.
cons: Management is not invested in the employees. They spend too much time focused on how they will make a difference. They do not enable others to make a difference. The best example of this is the Office of Innovation. Ideas come from the ideas team and not the staff or faculty.

job_title: Student Recruitment Coordinator in Rosenberg, TX
pros: You will gain a lot of experience if you are looking to use this job as a stepping stone for your career.
cons:
Every freaking thing. It was so bad that my direct manager quit, 3 of my recruiters quit, I was forced to fire people, and my VP recommended I fire someone because he wasn’t moving fast enough (which is weird because he still currently employed there). Eventually, I was fired for some dumb reason even though I put in nearly 3 years of my life towards this campus. They have high expectations for the person in this role (expect you to do mid senior to senior level work at an entry level salary), give no training, & yell at you the minute you make a mistake. When I was there, the Recruitment department was full of people who hate their job. It created such a toxic working environment. You’ll have people at other campuses that swear up and down it’s the best place to work…don’t believe them. Most of them have never had any other job other than a job at TSTC. It’s a sink or swim mentality, full of entitled fake Karens and Kens (literally)… not a diverse statewide campus at all. They tried to improve their diversity by hiring more people of color, but those people of color they hire tend to quit because they don’t survive the toxicity of that place. One my direct manager said “there are a lot of black people at the Fort Bend campus”… *Shakes head* Also, very little room to move up or grow in salary. Annual pay was 37k when I was initially hired and then moved to 42k only because a previous HR person (who eventually quit because it was so bad) fought for our salary and demanded it be increased due to market pay. This has been a long battle considering a lot of the senior employees at other campuses refused to see FB employees make more money than them with less years put in. Turnover rate here is HIGH. Saw this position posted 3 times since I’ve left in 2017, so that speaks for itself. STAY AWAY from this place unless the leadership in the Recruitment department changes. 

Also, when my father died, I only had 2 days of emergency leave with pay… the rest of my time off I used vacation days. What kind of crazy place makes their hardworking employees use vacation days when they are grieving?

pros: Able to help others succeed
cons: Frustrating sometimes due to different factors

pros: Friendly coworkers, and a good support system when needed.

review_title: Fun Student Worker Position in Enrollment Management

Easy

pros: The mission of the college is the single best reason to work at TSTC.
cons: Leadership must change. There is no concept of true change management, transparency, honesty, or true "family" working environment. Leadership does not understand the difference between espoused theory and theory in use. Use caution in giving more than you sign up for.

pros: Remote work, teamwork, and good employees

pros: I am Able to work from home

pros: There were a lot of pros

job_title: Student Recruitment Representative in Harlingen, TX
pros: Great pay, benefits, schedule, leadership. Employee tuition discount to encourage growth
cons: Pay is not keeping up with evolving job growth.

review_title: Beware of the Envious in Charge
pros: The employer offers retirement benefits.
cons: The administration collapses through adversity fairly often....This trampling is a latent risk and penalty for lower rank employees.... It usually ends in bad faith terminations with a makeup or fuss excuse, so the affected party (you) cannot receive Unemployment Benefits from Texas Workforce Commission. The student population and professional staff has folded to unacceptable levels many times in the last decade.

review_title: Fun place but will let you go with no notice
pros: Fun place to work. I really enjoyed interacting with potential students and their families.
cons: TSTC began to change in 2015. Employees were always well cared for but then suddenly they became very disposable. They began to let many long-term employees go with absolutely no notice. I was fortunate to not be one of those; I left of my own accord. They took away vital programs that were in high demand. TSTC went from being a place I loved and would highly recommend to everyone to a place I would discourage students from attending.

pros: Great insurance for employee and kids. Pension plan does not require you to give up social security as working for K-12 does.
cons: Raises are almost non-existent. Company uses stipends which must be voted on every year. This is because raises count toward your eventual pension plan payout, but stipends do not.

pros: Strong culture and values felt throughout the organization. Love 98% of my peers. Family feel.
cons: May need a few more hands in some departments for support

pros: This is a Great school
cons: There is really no cons for this school

pros: Caring, Pro active, a head of the curve
cons: I do not have any cons.

pros: Solid mission; opportunity to help transform the lives of students; practical impact of one’s work.
cons: Pay is significantly lower than comparable positions at similar colleges in the state; no stability (perpetual contracts that need to be renewed regularly); little room for advancement unless you have made the “right” internal connections; frequent changes and little say or even notice given to employees; turnover rate creates lack of stability

review_title: Decent job while going to school
pros: Flexible hours. Have the ability to study while on the clock.
cons: Loved the original boss I had until she was let go, current boss is a micromanager.

pros: Just a wonderful place to work
cons: Don't really have anything to add . Love it

job_title: Director of Recruiting in Rosenberg, TX
pros: Honestly there were no pros working for this company.
cons: This was one of the worst positions I ever had. I only worked here for about 3 months before I had to just quit. My direct supervisor was very unorganized. She would tell me I had to do this or that, then in the next breath tell me to do something else. Just Terrible.

pros: I enjoy mentoring and connecting with students.
cons: Internal communication is poor. Salary does not keep up with cost of living.

pros: Clearly mission-focused on student success and job placement. Making significant investments in instructional quality, facilities, and retaining talent. Strong brand with industry.
cons: Some campuses have outdated facilities in need of demolition. Website in need of complete overhaul. Growing pains associated with new process improvements.

pros:
Benefits 
>PTO 8hrs a month
>Sick Leave 8hrs a month
>Health Insurance free for employee only
cons: Chancellor and higher ups on 3rd floor don't care about their employees.  They have a "rules are for the but not for me" mentality.

job_title: Field Service Technician in Waco, TX
pros: Its like a family here and everyday is different.
cons: Not much room for raises in a position but can get promoted easy.

job_title: IT Implementation Specialist in Harlingen, TX
pros: Amazing people to work with

job_title: Business Unit Manager in Georgetown, TX
pros: Meaningful Purpose, Great Benefits, Great People
cons: Moves at the speed of Government

review_title: Bad Behind the times Compensation Philosphy
pros: Most of the jobs are really easy
cons:
Look at what everyone else is saying about this school, the compensation is BAD and out dated. I can't find people to fill my open positions because their making too much money and we can't match and then we can't keep our own people because we're losing them to everyone else who pays better than TSTC. Then all raises have been suspended (I bet not for the higher ups though) and there are no bonuses.
And then we all wonder about the leaders ethics and morals. Just look at the article in the Texas Tribune last January about how the chief financial officers company that pocketed a sweet deal to design and furnish the remodel of the main building. Don't tell me that wasn't a behind closed door deal. Those higher ups like to take care of there own instead of us who bust our tails for a living.

pros: Great student base, articulation, and degree program offerings.  Plenty of applicants.  Most other staff and faculty are here for the students and definitely not the money.  Plenty of work to streamline things including administration and their duties to actually manage things "appropriately".  Benefits are good along with TRS (do not go ORP, unless this is short gig).
cons: Cut, cut, cut!  Seems to be the motto now.  Administration salaries increase 10-15% a year.  Salary negotiation coming in the door seems to be for LIFE!  NO JOKE!  Top heavy and the Chancellor, who is now at $490K from the State of Texas "Gotta have money to make money", has got to go.   Must do more with less down here in the trenches.  Reorgs are now as rife as the gossip.  No transparency as promised.

pros: Can't really think of much except we received a 7% salary market differential increase. They could of rounded it up to 10%...even with the 7% increase the salary isn't enough to live comfortably.
cons: No maternity leave. You have to use your sick days or vacation days if an emergency comes up that passes the 3 paid emergency leave days. At the FB campus your boss more than likely resides at another campus 3-6 hrs away.

review_title: It is a good place to retire. Do not work here for a career.
pros: There is personal worth and value in educating others. The job can be flexible with work hours / using PTO in some departments. The retirement plan / benefits package is good.
cons: Management seems to not have a clear direction or will not share the overall direction honestly. There are micromanagers in middle to upper management. There are way too many upper level managers. There is little advancement or pay oppertunities and raises will not keep pace with inflation. I tend to work long hours with little to no recognition for effort or personal sacrifice.

review_title: Stay away. It will destroy your soul.
pros: Being able to work and mentor students, but you can find that in any academic setting.
cons: Any joy, motivation, inspiration, hard-work, and dedication will be drained from you. You will start out making excuses why they treat you like crap. Hoping to change the system, work hard and help others to make the school a great and prestigious place will get you nothing. No praise, no money, and most likely they will undo what you did. This organization is a MEAT grinder. It will take everything you have and give you NOTHING. Management can and will torture you. HR will not help you and will break the law to make sure they will not help you. STAY AWAY.. You are seriously more compensated to work at TACO BELL.

pros:
The staff here are friendly and helpful.  The Instructors are passionate about the students and truly want them students to succeed. 
The benefits are great.  The state of Texas pays for my medical benefit premium in full and half of the premium for my dependents.  The deductible is $25.  
I receive 15 paid holidays per year along with vacation AND sick time.
The Chancellor communicates with everyone effectively letting the entire staff know they are doing a great job.  It is my opinion that the Chancellor and his staff are on a good path with their strategic plans.
I enjoy working here and look forward to the future.
cons: It does not pay as much as the private sector but the time off and benefits make up for it.

pros:
-Good time-off, 8 hours vac. and sick each per month plus 14 paid holidays on top of this
-My boss is very lenient and understanding, willing to work with me if I have an emergency
-Co-workers are generally easy to work with
-Benefits are decent
cons:
-The pace of work is very slow, it's hard to get things done in an orderly and timely fashion
-Salary is horrible, also in speaking with those who have been here longest there have been very few raises
-Training is almost non-existent, I did get forklift certified here
-You spend most of your time waiting on administrative decisions before getting any work done, very bureaucratic environment
-No overtime pay, just comptime
-Does not compare well with other educational institutions in terms of salary, PTO, overtime

pros: Great people to work with, family is very important to them.
cons: No training, opportunity for advancement, or pay increases. when you take into account cost of living, I now make less than I did when I started. Very poor communication from upper management. Promotions may be given but you are unlikely to see an adjustment to your pay unless you are high enough up the chain. Tons of politics and petty power struggles by leadership.

pros: Job security is pretty strong. The benefits can also be a plus at times, like free healthcare and academic leave. Working with students is also rewarding in many ways, watching them excel at their assignments and mature into working professionals.
cons: The school also compensates their employees very poorly. They also seem to hire way too many people in administration positions rather than where employees are actually needed.

review_title: If you are over 50 looking for a place to earn a second retirement and don't care about pay, TSTC might be for you.
pros: Its a state job, with state benefits but most of these benefits are available with any employer. Matching 6.25% contributions to employer IRA, Standard Texas state TRS/ERS benefits, including free employer covered healthcare for the employee, $200 for employee and children, $400 for employee, children, spouse. Dental $35 per person. 1 year after hire you can take classes at TSTC at the associate level for $15 per cr hr, which for non-skilled labor would be a great deal, but if your already a professional with at least a 2yr degree its useless.
cons: Lower level supervisors and mid level management are much more concerned about keeping up the appearance of competence than suggestions for improvement, in fact they seem threatened by it. Many employees have been there for 10+ years in the same position and have the connections and political clout to keep from getting replace by qualified employees. The pay isn't satisfactory by any measure and although the chancellor has taken the initiative to do a survey of other colleges in the state to address pay issues those measure still haven't been implemented over a year and half later. Taking into account the cost of living in other metro areas you'd earn 35-50% more by staying in the private sector. However, pay isn't the biggest issue, the incompetence of your supervisors and managers are. Yes there are exceptions to this, but in the main on the day you graduate from the community college you'll be more qualified than the person you will report to and the worse part is knowing until they retire you won't be promoted. Working for this employer means staying in the same job for a decade or more.

review_title: OK, if you only need something to do later in life and expectation are not very high, can be fulfilling
pros: Freedom to experiment with various technologies and training provided to support position when budget is available
cons: two 3 percent raises in 11 years, cannot attend any training or conferences that support professional education out-of-state for staff and faculty

pros: If you love the trenches with real progress toward educational goals in practical hands-on, this is the place for you.  Just don't look at the salary.
cons: Politics and very little guarantee on merit based or state raises.  Academics rarely change, however other technologies are always evolving and therein lies the problem, training.  Get ready to self learn with limited resources.

pros: Health insurance, paid time off, retirement, working with the students.
cons: Because leadership can’t figure anything out, the rest of the college and employees suffer. There is constant “restructuring” within the college, where they push good employees out of their positions and create more chaos, but LT (leadership team) does not bother to communicate with the employees it affects.  Employees live in fear of losing their jobs and deal with toxic work environments on a daily basis.

review_title: A Great Environment to Work in
job_title: Student Services Manager in Waco, TX
pros: Good benefits.  Great time off, especially at Christmas time.  You work with and for people who care about you.
cons: The pay.  People are always looking for other jobs in order to make more money.  People stay for the benefits and time off, but sometimes that won't keep them here.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Waco, TX
pros: They are flexible with time outside of scheduled classes. This is depends on the department. The benefits are good.
cons: Upper management changes its mind too often. They do not let the effects of change take hold and then they change again. They are more concerned with their own careers than the well being of the school or the success of the students. The pay is not competitive to being a field technician. Generally, they have made a funky attitude that ruins the overall work environment,
